elements.content: By varying the metal to ligand ratio, stepwise formation of a series of homonuclear silver(I) complexes of a carbene-bridged bis-bipyridine ligand (L) was achieved. In the mononuclear 1:2 complex [AgL2]Br (1) only the carbene carbon is involved in the metal coordination, while both of the 2,2′-bipyridine (bpy) arms are free. When the amount of silver(I) ion was increased, isomorphous 2:2 dinuclear complexes with different counteranions, [Ag2L2]X2 (X = Br– (2a), PF6 – (2b), BPh4 – (2c)), were synthesized from the ligand LX, in which the carbene carbon and one of the bpy units participate in the coordination with silver(I) ions. Further addition of AgI salt afforded the one-dimensional coordination polymer {[Ag3L2](PF6)3·4CH3CN} n (3), wherein the hanging bipyridine units also coordinate with AgI and thus all the coordination sites of the ligand are employed. The results reveal the preference of AgI ion for the carbene carbon donor rather than the bpy units. The synthesis, structures, and interconversion of the complexes and the counteranion effects on the structures are reported, and the luminescent properties of the ligand LX and the silver complexes have also been studied.

elements.content: There has been intense interest in the supramolecular chemistry of silver(I) complexes because of their potential applications in various fields such as luminescent materials, host–guest chemistry, medicine, and catalysis. While various N-, O-, P-, and S-donor ligands were used traditionally in these systems, the AgI complexes of the N-heterocyclic carbenes (NHCs) have also emerged in recent years. Since the isolation of the first homoleptic AgI-carbene complex, the chemistry of this class of species has been extensively studied. Many Ag complexes of NHC-based ligands have been synthesized, which show diverse structures from two-coordinate linear molecules to complex helical structures, polymers, rings, cages, and clusters. These complexes could be readily prepared by treatment of Ag2O or other silver sources (e.g., AgOAc, Ag2CO3) with the corresponding imidazolium salts. More importantly, they can be widely used as NHC-transfer reagents to prepare Ru-, Ir-, Rh-, and Pt-NHC complexes and as possible antimicrobials or as efficient catalysts. In addition, the NHC ligands can be decorated with other functional coordinating groups, which makes them excellent building blocks for the construction of coordination architectures with desired properties.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

There has been intense interest in the supramolecular chemistry of silver(I) complexes because of their potential applications in various fields such as luminescent materials, host-guest chemistry, medicine, and catalysis. While various N-, O-, P-, and S-donor ligands were used traditionally in these systems, the AgI complexes of the N-heterocyclic carbenes (NHCs) have also emerged in recent years. Since the isolation of the first homoleptic AgI-carbene complex, the chemistry of this class of species has been extensively studied. Many Ag complexes of NHC-based ligands have been synthesized, which show diverse structures from two-coordinate linear molecules to complex helical structures, polymers, rings, cages, and clusters. These complexes could be readily prepared by treatment of Ag2O or other silver sources (e.g., AgOAc, Ag2CO3) with the corresponding imidazolium salts. More importantly, they can be widely used as NHC-transfer reagents to prepare Ru-, Ir-, Rh-, and Pt-NHC complexes and as possible antimicrobials or as efficient catalysts. In addition, the NHC ligands can be decorated with other functional coordinating groups, which makes them excellent building blocks for the construction of coordination architectures with desired properties.

elements.content: 2,2′-Bipyridine (bpy) and its derivatives have been the subject of numerous studies in coordination chemistry due to their excellent chelating properties and the exciting photophysical properties of their metal complexes. On the basis of these advantages, incorporating bpy groups on the NHC unit would create novel heterotopic NHC ligands, which can bring in interesting coordination chemistry. Moreover, these ligands may serve as good candidates for the construction of luminescent complexes, in which the chelating bipyridine subunits can give rise to the characteristic metal-to-ligand charge-transfer (MLCT) luminescence. For instance, Beer and co-workers have designed a variety of disubstituted 2,2′-bpy ligands with the imidazolium group and obtained the d–f heteronuclear [2]pseudorotaxanes, which can sensitize near-IR lanthanide emission upon coordination of the bpy units. On the other hand, the metal-NHC complexes, especially those of the d10 metals (Ag, Au), have also been reported to display interesting emissive properties.

For instance, Beer and co-workers have designed a variety of disubstituted 2,2'-bpy ligands with the imidazolium group and obtained the d-f heteronuclear [2]pseudorotaxanes, which can sensitize near-IR lanthanide emission upon coordination of the bpy units. On the other hand, the metal-NHC complexes, especially those of the d10 metals (Ag, Au), have also been reported to display interesting emissive properties.

elements.content: In this work we aimed to study the coordination behavior of heterotopic NHC-based ligands. A bis-bipyridyl-substituted imidazolium ligand (LX, X = Br–, PF6 –, BPh4 –) linked through CH2 groups was synthesized, which reacted with Ag2O to afford a series of silver(I) NHC complexes, [AgL2]Br (1), [Ag2L2]X2 (X = Br (2a), PF6 (2b), BPh4 (2c)), and {[Ag3L2](PF6)3·4CH3CN} n (3), when different metal to ligand ratios were used (Scheme ). With an increasing amount of silver(I) ion, the mononuclear complex 1 (M:L = 1:2), bimetallic complexes 2a–c (M:L = 2:2), and the polymeric structure 3 (M:L = 3:2) were in turn isolated. In the first two cases, the ligand does not reach coordination completeness (only the carbene carbon (in 1) or carbene and one of the bpy arms (in 2a–c) participate in coordination to the silver atom), while in complex 3 all of the coordination donors (the central carbene and two bpy arms) are employed to bind Ag atoms (Scheme ). Herein we report the synthesis and structures of these silver(I) complexes, the transformation among them, and their luminescent properties.

Results and DiscussionSynthesis

The ligand N,N′-bis[5-(2,2′-bipyridyl)methyl]imidazolium bromide (LBr) was prepared via the condensation of 5-bromomethyl-2,2′-bipyridine and imidazole in CH3CN as previously reported. The counteranion was exchanged by excess NH4PF6 or NaBPh4 to yield a white powder of LPF6 or LBPh4 in modest yields (51–60%). The 1H NMR spectrum proved the formation of the product by the appearance of a downfield resonance at 9.44 ppm for the acidic CH + protons of the imidazolium group. The bridging methylene (NimCH 2Npy) moiety appeared as a singlet at 5.56 ppm (Figure S1, ).

Results and Discussion

Synthesis

The ligand N,N'-bis[5-(2,2'-bipyridyl)methyl]imidazolium bromide (LBr) was prepared via the condensation of 5-bromomethyl-2,2'-bipyridine and imidazole in CH3CN as previously reported. The counteranion was exchanged by excess NH4PF6 or NaBPh4 to yield a white powder of LPF6 or LBPh4 in modest yields (51-60%). The 1H NMR spectrum proved the formation of the product by the appearance of a downfield resonance at 9.44 ppm for the acidic CH + protons of the imidazolium group. The bridging methylene (NimCH 2Npy) moiety appeared as a singlet at 5.56 ppm (Figure S1, ).

elements.content: The mononuclear Ag complex [AgL2]Br (1) was obtained by treating LBr with Ag2O in CH3CN at room temperature with an LBr:Ag ratio of 2:1. The analogous mononuclear silver complexes with the counterion PF6 – or BPh4 – can also be prepared in the same way by using LPF6 or LBPh4, respectively, as proved by the 1H NMR data (). The dinuclear complexes [Ag2L2]X2 (X = Br– (2a), PF6 – (2b), BPh4 – (2c)) were synthesized as white powders in moderate to good yields by the reaction of purified ligand LX with freshly prepared silver oxide in CH3CN solution, as illustrated in Scheme . Here the molar ratio of LX:Ag = 1:1 was used in the syntheses of the three complexes. On the other hand, we observed that complex 1 could also be obtained by immersing 2a in MeOH with exposure to light for 2 h, with accompanying formation of silver mirror on the wall of the tube (Figure S3, ). We supposed that oxidation of the solvent methanol might have taken place on the surface of 2a when it was exposed to light and thus the silver ions were consumed, but this conversion did not happen in the dark. For further evidence, we tested the stability of 2a in CH3CN, and only a small amount of Ag powder was found at the bottom of the tube upon exposure to light due to the decomposition of the compound.

elements.content: These Ag complexes are sparingly soluble in methanol and acetonitrile and decompose in DMSO and DMF. The 1H NMR spectra showed the absence of the imidazolium (CH +) resonance due to the loss of this acidic proton upon reaction with Ag2O, and the 13C NMR spectra revealed the appearance of a diagnostic silver-bound carbene (NCN–Ag) peak at 155.6 ppm for complex 1 and at 158.6 and 159.4 ppm for 2a,c, respectively. These values are comparable to those at the lower end of the rather wide range (ca. 210–160 ppm) reported for Ag–NHC complexes. The signal of the carbene carbon in 2b was not observed, and similar phenomena have been reported for some silver(I) carbene complexes, which may result from the fluxional behavior of the NHC complexes. The 1H NMR spectrum of complex 1 is relatively simple due to the high symmetry of the linearly coordinated AgI ion, which only gives rise to one sharp peak for the bridging CH2 protons at 4.93 ppm. In contrast, the less symmetric complexes 2a (5.43, 5.45 ppm) and 2c (5.37, 5.27 ppm) display two sharp peaks for the bridging CH2 groups. The formation of the complexes was also confirmed by X-ray crystal structures.

elements.content: Interestingly, in the bimetallic complexes 2a–c, one of the bpy subunits of the ligand L is free and may further coordinate to secondary metal ions. Attempts to utilize the complexes [Ag2L2]X2 and [AgL2]Br as building blocks to interact with other metal salts have failed to produce any heterometallic complexes. However, the homometallic coordination polymer {[Ag3L2](PF6)3·4CH3CN} n (3) was obtained as a light yellow crystalline material by treatment of [Ag2L2](PF6)2 (2b) with an excess of AgPF6 in acetonitrile (Scheme ). Complex 3 is stable in the solid state, but in solution and upon exposure to air and light the solution immediately changes from light yellow to brown. X-ray crystallography of 3 revealed that the [Ag2L2](PF6)2 units are linked by Ag+ ions to yield an infinite one-dimensional chain, which further extends to a 3D structure through hydrogen bonding with the PF6 – counterions and CH3CN solvents.

However, the homometallic coordination polymer {[Ag3L2](PF6)3⋅4CH3CN} n  (3) was obtained as a light yellow crystalline material by treatment of [Ag2L2](PF6)2 (2b) with an excess of AgPF6 in acetonitrile (Scheme ). elements.content: Colorless block crystals of the silver(I) complexes [AgL2]Br (1), [Ag2L2]X2 (X = Br (2a), PF6 (2b)) and light yellow block crystals of [Ag2L2](BPh4)2 (2c) and {[Ag3L2](PF6)3·4CH3CN} n (3) were formed by slow diffusion of ether into CH3CN solutions of the compounds over 1 week. In the 1:2 complex 1, the Ag atom is linearly coordinated by two carbene carbon atoms from two ligands and all of the bpy units are uncoordinated. The dinuclear complexes 2a–c are isomorphous, in which the Ag+ ion is triply coordinated in a distorted-trigonal-planar geometry by the nitrogen atoms of a bpy subunit in one ligand and the carbene carbon atom from the other ligand. Thus, the complexes are dimerized with a slippage through a bpy unit to a carbene moiety of the other L molecule. As mentioned above, one of the bpy arms of each ligand remains hanging. In the polymeric complex 3, however, all the N donors are coordinated. The crystal data for 2a are poor, and therefore, the structures of 1, 2b,c and 3 will be discussed in detail. These complexes clearly demonstrate the rich coordination modes of silver(I) ion from two- to three- to four-coordinate, leading to various geometries from linear (1) to trigonal (2a–c) and square-planar patterns (3).

Crystal Structures

Colorless block crystals of the silver(I) complexes [AgL2]Br (1), [Ag2L2]X2 (X = Br (2a), PF6 (2b)) and light yellow block crystals of [Ag2L2](BPh4)2 (2c) and {[Ag3L2](PF6)3⋅4CH3CN} n  (3) were formed by slow diffusion of ether into CH3CN solutions of the compounds over 1 week. In the 1:2 complex 1, the Ag atom is linearly coordinated by two carbene carbon atoms from two ligands and all of the bpy units are uncoordinated. The dinuclear complexes 2a-c are isomorphous, in which the Ag+ ion is triply coordinated in a distorted-trigonal-planar geometry by the nitrogen atoms of a bpy subunit in one ligand and the carbene carbon atom from the other ligand. Thus, the complexes are dimerized with a slippage through a bpy unit to a carbene moiety of the other L molecule. As mentioned above, one of the bpy arms of each ligand remains hanging. In the polymeric complex 3, however, all the N donors are coordinated. The crystal data for 2a are poor, and therefore, the structures of 1, 2b,c and 3 will be discussed in detail. These complexes clearly demonstrate the rich coordination modes of silver(I) ion from two- to three- to four-coordinate, leading to various geometries from linear (1) to trigonal (2a-c) and square-planar patterns (3).

elements.content: Complex 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c, with half of the Ag+ ion, one L molecule, and half of the bromide anion occupying the asymmetric unit. The bromide atom is disordered over two positions with half-occupancy each. The Ag atom resides on a crystallographic inversion center and thus displays a perfectly linear two-coordinate geometry (Figure ) with a Ag–C(carbene) distance of 2.069(6) Å, which is shorter than the sum of individual covalent radii (2.111 Å) of Ag and C and is comparable to those in recently reported silver(I) NHC complexes. The bpy rings in the same ligand point to opposite sides of the imidazole plane (“S” shape). The two coordinated imidazole rings are strictly coplanar, which is quite different from the case for the reported complexes [((pyCH2)2-im)2Ag]Cl and {[1-mes-3-(N-CH2CONHPh)im-2-ylidene]2Ag}Cl, in which the two imidazole rings are canted with dihedral angles of 5.2 and 57.7°, respectively. In the extended structure, the [AgL2] units are connected through C–H···O (2.88(2) Å) hydrogen bonds between bpy units and solvent H2O and C–H···Br bonds (3.52–3.72(9) Å) between bpy units and Br– ions, and thus a 1D strand is formed along the a axis (Figure S4, ).

Complex 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c, with half of the Ag+ ion, one L molecule, and half of the bromide anion occupying the asymmetric unit. The bromide atom is disordered over two positions with half-occupancy each. The Ag atom resides on a crystallographic inversion center and thus displays a perfectly linear two-coordinate geometry (Figure ) with a Ag-C(carbene) distance of 2.069(6) Å, which is shorter than the sum of individual covalent radii (2.111 Å) of Ag and C and is comparable to those in recently reported silver(I) NHC complexes. The bpy rings in the same ligand point to opposite sides of the imidazole plane ("S" shape). In the extended structure, the [AgL2] units are connected through C-H⋅⋅⋅O (2.88(2) Å) hydrogen bonds between bpy units and solvent H2O and C-H⋅⋅⋅Br bonds (3.52-3.72(9) Å) between bpy units and Br- ions, and thus a 1D strand is formed along the a axis (Figure S4, ).

elements.content: The disilver(I) complex 2b crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c. The structure is free of crystal solvents, and the asymmetric unit contains half of the molecule, in which the PF6 – ion plays charge-balance and space-filling roles. A perspective view of the dinuclear structure is depicted in Figure . The Ag atom adopts a three-coordinate, distorted-trigonal-planar geometry consisting of two nitrogen atoms (N5i and N6i) from a bpy unit and one carbene carbon atom (C14) from the other ligand, and the dimeric structure is gained by symmetry transformation (1 – x, 1 – y, −z). In the coordination sphere, the Ag atom deviates from the trigonal plane (N5i, N6i, C14) by 0.164 Å, while the imidazole ring is nearly perpendicular to the coordination plane (dihedral angle 77.9°). The two pyridyl rings within one uncoordinated bpy are not coplanar but have a dihedral angle of 10.9°. Notably, the binding mode of this dinulear complex is different from that of the octahedral diiron(II) or dicopper(II) triple-stranded helicates M2L3 formed with the same ligand L. In the latter complexes the two terminal bpy units participate in the coordination with metal ions, but the bridging imidazolium groups are involved in anion binding.

The structure is free of crystal solvents, and the asymmetric unit contains half of the molecule, in which the PF6 - ion plays charge-balance and space-filling roles. A perspective view of the dinuclear structure is depicted in Figure . The Ag atom adopts a three-coordinate, distorted-trigonal-planar geometry consisting of two nitrogen atoms (N5i and N6i) from a bpy unit and one carbene carbon atom (C14) from the other ligand, and the dimeric structure is gained by symmetry transformation (1 - x, 1 - y, -z). In the coordination sphere, the Ag atom deviates from the trigonal plane (N5i, N6i, C14) by 0.164 Å, while the imidazole ring is nearly perpendicular to the coordination plane (dihedral angle 77.9°). The two pyridyl rings within one uncoordinated bpy are not coplanar but have a dihedral angle of 10.9°. Notably, the binding mode of this dinulear complex is different from that of the octahedral diiron(II) or dicopper(II) triple-stranded helicates M2L3 formed with the same ligand L. elements.content: The Ag–carbene distance (2.073(10) Å) is slightly longer than that of complex 1 (2.069(6) Å), and the Ag–bpy bonds (2.331(9) and 2.248(10) Å) are within the normal range observed in similar silver(I) bpy complexes. The bite angle N5i–Ag–N6i (71.0(3)°) is smaller than those in reported silver(I) polypyridyl complexes. In contrast to the anti orientation of the two bpy subunits in complex 1, the ligand in 2b shows a pseudo-syn conformation: i.e., the two bpy arms are located at the same side of the imidazole plane (“C” shape). The coordinated bpy unit bends more to the central imidazole plane (N4–C15–C16, 109.5(8)°), while the uncoordinated bpy arm expands slightly away (N3–C11–C9, 112.5(9)°; Figure ). The reason why the free bpy arms tend to adopt such a crowding conformation may be attributed to the π–π stacking interactions between a pyridyl ring of the free bpy arm and the metal chelate ring (centroid···centroid distance 3.677 Å, dihedral angle 10.8°; Figure ). The Ag···Ag separation of 6.14 Å excludes any Ag–Ag interaction. Compound 2b exists as infinite strands in the extended solid-state structure held together by a series of C–H···F (3.06–3.66 Å) hydrogen bonds between PF6 – and the L ligands (Figure S5, ).

In contrast to the anti orientation of the two bpy subunits in complex 1, the ligand in 2b shows a pseudo-syn conformation: i.e., the two bpy arms are located at the same side of the imidazole plane ("C" shape). The coordinated bpy unit bends more to the central imidazole plane (N4-C15-C16, 109.5(8)°), while the uncoordinated bpy arm expands slightly away (N3-C11-C9, 112.5(9)°; Figure ). The reason why the free bpy arms tend to adopt such a crowding conformation may be attributed to the π-π stacking interactions between a pyridyl ring of the free bpy arm and the metal chelate ring (centroid⋅⋅⋅centroid distance 3.677 Å, dihedral angle 10.8°; Figure ). The Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag separation of 6.14 Å excludes any Ag-Ag interaction. Compound 2b exists as infinite strands in the extended solid-state structure held together by a series of C-H⋅⋅⋅F (3.06-3.66 Å) hydrogen bonds between PF6 - and the L ligands (Figure S5, ).

elements.content: Light yellow block crystals of 2c also crystallize in the monoclinic space group P21/c, but the asymmetric unit consists of a whole dimeric complex [Ag2L2](BPh4)2 (without crystal-imposed symmetry), as well as one water and two acetonitrile molecules. In 2c, each AgI cation adopts a distorted-trigonal geometry and is coordinated by a chelating 2,2′-bpy moiety and a carbene carbon atom from the other ligand (Figure ), as in the analogous complex 2b. The mean Ag–carbene distance (2.067(9) Å) is shorter than in 2b (2.073(10) Å) but is comparable with that in 1 (2.069(6) Å), and the N–Ag–N bite angle (72.3(3)°) is slightly larger than in 2b. The Ag1 atom deviates from the corresponding coordinate trigonal plane (N1, N2, C39) by 0.157 Å as in 2b, but the Ag2 atom is coplanar with its coordinate plane (N7, N8, C14). In addition, the imidazole rings are also nearly perpendicular to the coordinate planes (dihedral angles 83.4 and 87.7°, respectively), and the two pyridyl rings are not coplanar (dihedral angles 6.9 and 15.1°) in the uncoordinated bpy units.

elements.content: However, there are also differences between 2b and 2c in the solid-state structure. The “C”-shaped ligands in 2c are arranged across each other around the AgI centers. The orientation of the two hanging bpy units in 2c is roughly perpendicular, while in 2b they are parallel. This may be caused by the cation–anion interactions of different counteranions in the two cases. In 2b, the bpy units and the PF6 – ions form CH···F hydrogen bonds (Figure S5, ), but in complex 2c the strong CH···π contacts between L and BPh4 – ions and the larger steric crowding of the much bigger BPh4 – ion force the bpy units to be arranged in an orthogonal fashion (Figure S6, ). The adjacent complex molecules are connected by intermolecular C–H···N (3.47 and 3.22 Å) hydrogen bonds and C–H···π (3.4–3.5 Å) interactions between L and BPh4 – ions ().

elements.content: Air-stable yellow crystals of the 1D infinite chain compound {[Ag3L2](PF6)3·4CH3CN} n (3) were isolated by slowly diffusing ether into its CH3CN solution. The repeating unit consists of three AgI ions, two L ligands, three PF6 – counteranions, and four CH3CN solvent molecules. In this complex, the additional silver(I) ions are bridged by the ligand molecules through the hanging bpy units in 2a–c (Figure a). This symmetric structure is fairly uncommon, showing Ag atoms in two different environments. One silver atom (Ag1) adopts a three-coordinate trigonal-planar geometry comprising two nitrogen atoms (N1 and N2) from a bipyridyl unit and one carbon atom (C14) from the second ligand, as in the cases of 2b,c. The Ag–Nbpy bond distances are 2.322(6) and 2.301(5) Å, which lie in the range for bipyridine silver(I) complexes. The Ag–Ccarbene bond length (2.092(6) Å) is comparable to those observed in other silver(I) NHC complexes, and the N2–Ag1–N1 angle of 71.32(19)° is also comparable to those of 2b,c with the same coordinate environment. The second silver center (Ag2) is in a four-coordinate arrangement composed of four nitrogen atoms of two bipyridyl units from two separate ligands, with a τ4 value of 0.00 (for a perfect square-planar geometry). This is significantly different from most of the bipyridine silver(I) complexes, in which the AgI center often adopts a distorted-tetrahedral geometry. The Ag2–Nbpy bond distances range from 2.33(6) to 2.37(9) Å, and the N–Ag–N bite angle of the bipyridyl subunits is 70.3(2)°.

elements.content: In comparison with the dimeric complexes 2a–c, all of the coordination sites of the ligand L in complex 3 participate in the coordination with the Ag+ ion. The major structural features of 3 are somewhat similar to those of complex 2b, but the dinuclear units expand further through the free terminal bpy groups, coordinating to extra silver ions to form the coordination polymer 3. In the 1D chain structure of 3, two three-coordinate Ag atoms and one four-coordinate Ag atom are arranged alternately (Figure b and ). The Ag+ ions follow a zigzag path with Ag–Ag–Ag internal angles of 113.2 and 180° and Ag···Ag separations of 5.16 (Ag1···Ag2ii) and 5.93 Å (Ag1i···Ag2), respectively (Figure a). The adjacent chains are held together by a series of CH···F (3.17 to 3.51 Å) and CH···N (3.40 to 3.56 Å) hydrogen-bonding interactions between PF6 – counterions or CH3CN solvent molecules and the ligands, thereby forming a 2D layer. The Ag1···Ag1i separation of 5.93 Å within one dinuclear fragment is shorter than in complex 2b.

The adjacent chains are held together by a series of CH⋅⋅⋅F (3.17 to 3.51 Å) and CH⋅⋅⋅N (3.40 to 3.56 Å) hydrogen-bonding interactions between PF6 - counterions or CH3CN solvent molecules and the ligands, thereby forming a 2D layer. elements.content: The complexes reported here may exemplify the possibilities of substituted N-heterocyclic carbenes as ligands for silver(I) metal to generate novel homonuclear complexes. The complexes are air- and light-stable in the solid state, but the coordination polymer 3 appears to decompose partially in solution when exposed to light, accompanied by a color change (from yellow to brown) and the appearance of black Ag powder at the bottom of tube. In the construction of these silver complexes, the M:L ratio, solvent, and counteranion play crucial roles. As mentioned above, controlling the M:L ratio may result in the 1:2 (1), 2:2 (2a–c), and 3:2 (3) complexes, in which the carbene carbon donor is preferred by the Ag+ ion rather than the bpy units. The coordination sites display the affinity order AgC2 > AgCN2 > AgN4. Similar phenomena were also observed in Ag-NHC complexes decorated with pyridine groups. The solvent may also affect the formation of the complexes, as methanol can promote the conversion of 2a to 1. Finally, although isomorphous dinuclear structures 2a–c were obtained under similar conditions with different counteranions, some of their structural features are significantly different (vide supra). Such a diversity in structure may lead to variable physical and chemical properties, as shown below in the luminescence studies.

elements.content: The d10 configuration of the silver ion can combine with the π* orbitals of the ligands to produce metal to ligand charge-transfer (MLCT) and/or intraligand (IL) transitions, which result in the luminescence of these systems. Ag-NHC complexes also show fascinating photophysical properties, which can be strongly affected by the nature of the ligand. In the present work, the luminescent properties of the carbene-bridged bis-bipyridine ligands (with different anions) and the silver complexes were investigated in the solid state at room temperature (Figure and Table ). The analogous NHC ligands are photoluminescent in the solid state, as reported in the literature. The tetraphenylborate salt of the ligand (LBPh4) displays a very weak and broad emission at 465 nm (λex 375 nm), while strong luminescence is observed at 417 nm (br) for LPF6 and at 404 nm (br) for LBF4 upon irradiation at 350 and 343 nm, respectively (Figure ). Notably, the emission spectrum of the bromide analogue LBr shows three peaks (402, 425, and 452 nm). These emission peaks may originate from the π* → π transition of the ligand. Thus, the emission properties of the ligand can be tuned by the counteranion, which may affect the geometry of the excited state.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescence Studies

The d10 configuration of the silver ion can combine with the π* orbitals of the ligands to produce metal to ligand charge-transfer (MLCT) and/or intraligand (IL) transitions, which result in the luminescence of these systems. Ag-NHC complexes also show fascinating photophysical properties, which can be strongly affected by the nature of the ligand. In the present work, the luminescent properties of the carbene-bridged bis-bipyridine ligands (with different anions) and the silver complexes were investigated in the solid state at room temperature (Figure  and Table ). The analogous NHC ligands are photoluminescent in the solid state, as reported in the literature. The tetraphenylborate salt of the ligand (LBPh4) displays a very weak and broad emission at 465 nm (λex 375 nm), while strong luminescence is observed at 417 nm (br) for LPF6 and at 404 nm (br) for LBF4 upon irradiation at 350 and 343 nm, respectively (Figure ). Notably, the emission spectrum of the bromide analogue LBr shows three peaks (402, 425, and 452 nm). These emission peaks may originate from the π* → π transition of the ligand. Thus, the emission properties of the ligand can be tuned by the counteranion, which may affect the geometry of the excited state.

At 77 K, λex 390 nm.

As mentioned above, the AgI complexes 1, 2a–c, and 3 may exhibit luminescent behavior due to structural rearrangements associated with ligand coordination. The emission bands of complexes 1 and 2a,c lie in the visible region, showing blue luminescence. Complex 1 displays a broad emission band at 480 nm upon excitation at 390 nm (Figure ), which is quite different from the ligand LBr, which has three emission peaks with a maximum at 425 nm. Complexes 2a,c show a strong and broad emission band at 469 and 465 nm, respectively, upon excitation at 390 nm. A comparison with the corresponding ligands demonstrates that these luminescence signals are based on ligand-centered n−π* or π–π* processes. Broad emission bands at 508, 532, and 638 nm for 2b and 488, 515, and 624 nm for 3 were observed upon excitation at 415 and 399 nm, respectively. The origin of the emission at 532 and 515 nm might be the result of metal-perturbed intraligand (IL) transitions, whereas the high-energy emission at 400–490 nm is mainly associated with intraligand π–π* transitions. The emission observed at 638 nm for 2b and 624 nm for 3 may be due to metal to ligand charge transfer (MLCT), which is also consistent with the fluorescence of a simple Ag complex [Ag2L2(ClO4)2] (L = 4,5-diazospirobifluorene, a bipyridine-like ligand). Complexes 2a,c and 1 do not emit in this region but show dominating intramolecular π–π* interactions of the ligands. Hence, the luminescence properties observed for complexes 1, 2a–c, and 3 reflect a significant rearrangement of the ligand with varying ligation modes. It is noteworthy that only a few AgI-containing coordination polymers exhibit such characteristic emissions above 600 nm. The emission intensity of the silver complexes is fairly weak in comparison to that of the free ligands (Figures S8 and S9, ), which could be ascribed to the change of the environmental rigidity by coordination or the heavy atom effect of Ag. Moreover, the vast majority of AgI complexes are known to emit at low temperatures, while only a few monomeric and polymeric Ag complexes display intense photoluminescence at room temperature.

elements.content: The luminescent properties of the silver complexes were also investigated at 77 K in the solid state (Figure ). In comparison to the corresponding emission behavior at room temperature, complexes 1 and 2b show a blue shift (ca. 20–60 nm) of the higher energy bands (452 and 448 nm, respectively) at 77 K, while 2a,c and 3 display red-shifted emission bands with increased intensities. These results could be related to the thermal contraction that leads to a reduction in activity of the ligand and increase of the stability. The MLCT band of complex 3 is sharpened and red-shifted. The photoluminescent behavior of complexes 2a–c with similar structures but different counteranions varies significantly, which is caused by the change of the environmental rigidity resulting from the interactions of the surrounding anions, as discussed for the solid-state structures. The luminescence lifetimes of the complexes were measured at room temperature in acetonitrile solution (Table and Figures S10–S13 ()). Complexes 1 and 2a,b show triple-exponential decays, and the lifetime of 2a is longer than those of the others. In contrast, complex 2c displays a biexponential decay, which is also consistent with the case for most Ag-NHC complexes. The lifetime of 3 was not shown because of the poor stability of the complex in solution. Moreover, the results suggest no phosphorescence for any of the complexes.

elements.content: The synthesis, structures, and luminescent properties of a series of silver(I) complexes with an imidazolium-bridged bis-bipyridyl ligand and different counteranions have been reported. By controlling the ratio of Ag to ligand, stepwise formation of the 1:2 (complex 1), 2:2 (2a–c), and 3:2 (3) (M:L) complexes can be realized, in which the carbene carbon donor shows a priority over the bpy units when coordinating with the silver(I) ion. Hence, the coordinately incomplete ligands are present in the complexes 1 and 2a–c (one or two bpy units are free), while in 3 all the coordination donors are involved in the metal coordination. The counteranion and solvent have significant effects on the structure of the resulting complex. The structural diversity is also reflected in the different photophysical properties of the complexes.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

The synthesis, structures, and luminescent properties of a series of silver(I) complexes with an imidazolium-bridged bis-bipyridyl ligand and different counteranions have been reported. By controlling the ratio of Ag to ligand, stepwise formation of the 1:2 (complex 1), 2:2 (2a-c), and 3:2 (3) (M:L) complexes can be realized, in which the carbene carbon donor shows a priority over the bpy units when coordinating with the silver(I) ion. Hence, the coordinately incomplete ligands are present in the complexes 1 and 2a-c (one or two bpy units are free), while in 3 all the coordination donors are involved in the metal coordination. The counteranion and solvent have significant effects on the structure of the resulting complex. The structural diversity is also reflected in the different photophysical properties of the complexes.

elements.content: Reagent grade chemicals from commercial sources were used as received. Solvents were purified and dried according to standard methods. Ag2O was prepared prior to use. 5-Methyl-2,2′-bipyridine was prepared by the traditional Kröhnke procedure from 2-acetylpyridine and methacrolein following an adapted procedure. 5-Bromomethyl-2,2′-bipyridine was prepared according to the literature procedure by the reaction of 5-methyl-2,2′-bipyridine with an excess of NBS with AIBN as initiator under an N2 atmosphere. The ligand N,N′-bis[5-(2,2′-bipyridyl)methyl]imidazolium bromide (LBr) was prepared by following previously published procedures. 1H and 13C NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker AV400 instrument with calibration against the solvent signal (CD3CN and DMSO-d 6, 1.94 and 2.50 ppm for 1H, respectively). Elemental analyses were performed on a VarioEL instrument from Elementaranalysensysteme GmbH. Melting points were detected on an X-4 Digital Vision MP Instrument. Fluorescence spectra were measured at room temperature or 77 K (Hitachi F-7000 spectrophotometer). Emission lifetime experiments were carried out on a Horiba Jobin-Yvon FluoroMax-4 spectrophotometer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Procedures

Reagent grade chemicals from commercial sources were used as received. Solvents were purified and dried according to standard methods. Ag2O was prepared prior to use. 5-Methyl-2,2'-bipyridine was prepared by the traditional Kröhnke procedure from 2-acetylpyridine and methacrolein following an adapted procedure. 5-Bromomethyl-2,2'-bipyridine was prepared according to the literature procedure by the reaction of 5-methyl-2,2'-bipyridine with an excess of NBS with AIBN as initiator under an N2 atmosphere. The ligand N,N'-bis[5-(2,2'-bipyridyl)methyl]imidazolium bromide (LBr) was prepared by following previously published procedures. 1H and 13C NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker AV400 instrument with calibration against the solvent signal (CD3CN and DMSO-d 6, 1.94 and 2.50 ppm for 1H, respectively). Elemental analyses were performed on a VarioEL instrument from Elementaranalysensysteme GmbH. Melting points were detected on an X-4 Digital Vision MP Instrument. Fluorescence spectra were measured at room temperature or 77 K (Hitachi F-7000 spectrophotometer). Emission lifetime experiments were carried out on a Horiba Jobin-Yvon FluoroMax-4 spectrophotometer.

elements.content: Data collection was performed on a Bruker-AXS SMART CCD area detector diffractometer at 150 K with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.710 73 Å). Multiscan corrections were applied using SADABS. Structure solutions and refinements were performed with the SHELX-97 package. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically by full-matrix least squares on F 2. The hydrogen atoms were included in idealized geometric positions with thermal parameters equivalent to 1.2 times those of carbon and nitrogen atoms. Hydrogen atoms of water molecules in some complexes were not included. Crystallographic data are summarized in Table S1 ().
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

Data collection was performed on a Bruker-AXS SMART CCD area detector diffractometer at 150 K with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Multiscan corrections were applied using SADABS. Structure solutions and refinements were performed with the SHELX-97 package. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically by full-matrix least squares on F 2. The hydrogen atoms were included in idealized geometric positions with thermal parameters equivalent to 1.2 times those of carbon and nitrogen atoms. Hydrogen atoms of water molecules in some complexes were not included. Crystallographic data are summarized in Table S1 ().

cln_elements.content:
As mentioned above, the AgI complexes 1, 2a–c, and 3 may exhibit luminescent behavior due to structural rearrangements associated with ligand coordination. The emission bands of complexes 1 and 2a,c lie in the visible region, showing blue luminescence. Complex 1 displays a broad emission band at 480 nm upon excitation at 390 nm (Figure ), which is quite different from the ligand LBr, which has three emission peaks with a maximum at 425 nm. Complexes 2a,c show a strong and broad emission band at 469 and 465 nm, respectively, upon excitation at 390 nm. A comparison with the corresponding ligands demonstrates that these luminescence signals are based on ligand-centered n−π* or π–π* processes. Broad emission bands at 508, 532, and 638 nm for 2b and 488, 515, and 624 nm for 3 were observed upon excitation at 415 and 399 nm, respectively. The origin of the emission at 532 and 515 nm might be the result of metal-perturbed intraligand (IL) transitions, whereas the high-energy emission at 400–490 nm is mainly associated with intraligand π–π* transitions. The emission observed at 638 nm for 2b and 624 nm for 3 may be due to metal to ligand charge transfer (MLCT), which is also consistent with the fluorescence of a simple Ag complex [Ag2L2(ClO4)2] (L = 4,5-diazospirobifluorene, a bipyridine-like ligand). Complexes 2a,c and 1 do not emit in this region but show dominating intramolecular π–π* interactions of the ligands. Hence, the luminescence properties observed for complexes 1, 2a–c, and 3 reflect a significant rearrangement of the ligand with varying ligation modes. It is noteworthy that only a few AgI-containing coordination polymers exhibit such characteristic emissions above 600 nm. The emission intensity of the silver complexes is fairly weak in comparison to that of the free ligands (Figures S8 and S9, ), which could be ascribed to the change of the environmental rigidity by coordination or the heavy atom effect of Ag. Moreover, the vast majority of AgI complexes are known to emit at low temperatures, while only a few monomeric and polymeric Ag complexes display intense photoluminescence at room temperature.

Ag<sub>2</sub>L<sub>2</sub>(PF<sub>6</sub>)<sub>2</sub> (<bold>2b</bold>)

Yield: 58 mg, 86%. Mp: >300 °C. Anal. Calcd for Ag2L2(PF6)2 (C50H40Ag2F12N12P2): C, 45.68; H, 3.07; N, 12.79. Found: C, 45.41; H, 3.21; N, 12.48. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CD3CN, 25 °C): δ 8.65 (d, J = 4.8 Hz, 4H, H6′/H3a), 8.49 (s, 4H, H6/H3a′), 7.74–7.71 (m, 8H, H3/H3′, H4a/H4a′), 7.66–7.62 (m, 4H, H4′/H5a′), 7.48–7.50 (m, 4H, H4/H6a), 7.19 (s, 4H, Ha), 7.18–7.17 (m, 4H, H5′/H6a′), 5.07 (s, 8H, CH 2). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CD3CN, 25 °C): δ 149.2, 149.1, 137.5, 137.2, 129.3, 124.2, 122.7, 120.7, 120.6, 50.0, 39.5. Note: the signal for the carbene carbon was not observed.

Ag<sub>2</sub>L<sub>2</sub>(BPh<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>·2CH<sub>3</sub>CN·H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>2c</bold>)

Yield: 37 mg, 60%. Mp: >300 °C. Anal. Calcd for Ag2L2(BPh4)2·CH3CN (C100H83Ag2N13B2): C, 70.48; H, 4.91; N, 10.68. Found: C, 70.32; H, 4.91; N, 10.58. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CD3CN, 25 °C): δ 8.27 (d, J = 4.2 Hz, 4H, H6′/H3a), 8.16 (s, 4H, H6/H3a′), 7.79–7.75 (m, 8H, H3/H3′, H4a/H4a′), 7.68–7.62 (m, 4H, H4′/H5a′), 7.56–7.50 (m, 4H, H4/H6a), 7.26 (s, 40H, BPh4), 7.19 (s, 4H, Ha), 7.01–6.97 (m, 2H, H6a′), 6.85–6.82 (m, 2H, H5′), 5.37 (s, 4H, CH 2), 5.27 (s, 4H, CH 2). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CD3CN, 25 °C): δ 159.4, 149.4, 149.3, 148.7, 148.6, 148.5, 148.4, 137.5, 137.2, 136.8, 136.7, 136.6, 135.4, 124.4, 124.3, 122.5, 121.6, 120.8, 120.7, 117.8, 65.2, 52.2.

Found: C, 45.41; H, 3.21; N, 12.48. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CD3CN, 25 °C): δ 8.65 (d, J = 4.8 Hz, 4H, H6'/H3a), 8.49 (s, 4H, H6/H3a'), 7.74-7.71 (m, 8H, H3/H3', H4a/H4a'), 7.66-7.62 (m, 4H, H4'/H5a'), 7.48-7.50 (m, 4H, H4/H6a), 7.19 (s, 4H, Ha), 7.18-7.17 (m, 4H, H5'/H6a'), 5.07 (s, 8H, CH 2). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CD3CN, 25 °C): δ 149.2, 149.1, 137.5, 137.2, 129.3, 124.2, 122.7, 120.7, 120.6, 50.0, 39.5. Note: the signal for the carbene carbon was not observed.

Ag2L2(BPh4)2⋅2CH3CN⋅H2O (2c)

Yield: 37 mg, 60%. Mp: >300 °C. Anal. Calcd for Ag2L2(BPh4)2⋅CH3CN (C100H83Ag2N13B2): C, 70.48; H, 4.91; N, 10.68. Found: C, 70.32; H, 4.91; N, 10.58. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CD3CN, 25 °C): δ 8.27 (d, J = 4.2 Hz, 4H, H6'/H3a), 8.16 (s, 4H, H6/H3a'), 7.79-7.75 (m, 8H, H3/H3', H4a/H4a'), 7.68-7.62 (m, 4H, H4'/H5a'), 7.56-7.50 (m, 4H, H4/H6a), 7.26 (s, 40H, BPh4), 7.19 (s, 4H, Ha), 7.01-6.97 (m, 2H, H6a'), 6.85-6.82 (m, 2H, H5'), 5.37 (s, 4H, CH 2), 5.27 (s, 4H, CH 2). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CD3CN, 25 °C): δ 159.4, 149.4, 149.3, 148.7, 148.6, 148.5, 148.4, 137.5, 137.2, 136.8, 136.7, 136.6, 135.4, 124.4, 124.3, 122.5, 121.6, 120.8, 120.7, 117.8, 65.2, 52.2.
